Trial_Design.evidence: One hundred and sixty two cancer patients undergoing thoracotomy were randomized

Intervention.evidence: acupuncture technique specially developed for a surgical oncology population (intervention) reduces pain or analgesic use after thoracotomy compared to a sham acupuncture technique (control)

Objective.evidence: Objective: To determine whether an acupuncture technique specially developed for a surgical oncology population (intervention) reduces pain or analgesic use after thoracotomy compared to a sham acupuncture technique (control).

Method_Outcome.evidence: Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) of pain and total opioid use we evaluated during the in-patient stay; Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) and Medication Quantification Scale (MQS) were evaluated after discharge up to 3 months after the surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: One hundred and sixty two cancer patients undergoing thoracotomy were randomized

Result_Outcome.evidence: Pain scores were marginally higher in the intervention group 0.05 (95% C.I.: 0.74, -0.64; p=0.9).
